column2: Oh, but, said Scrap quickly, for he could not have come on a better day, when up there waiting and watching for her was, she knew, the enamoured Briggs, "I'm really very glad indeed to see you.
column3: Oh, but, said Scrap quickly, for he could not have come on a better day, when up there waiting and watching for her was, she knew, the enamoured Briggs, "I'm really very glad indeed to see you.

column2: Tell me about mother."
column3: Tell me about mother."

column2: Chapter 20

column2: Scrap wanted to know so much about her mother that Arundel had presently to invent.
column3: Scrap wanted to know so much about her mother that Arundel had presently to invent.

column2: He would talk about anything she wished if only he might be with her for a while and see her and hear her, but he knew very little of the Droitwiches and their friends really--beyond meeting them at those bigger functions where literature is also represented, and amusing them at luncheons and dinners, he knew very little of them really.
column3: He would talk about anything she wished if only he might be with her for a while and see her and hear her, but he knew very little of the Droitwiches and their friends really-beyond meeting them at those bigger functions where literature is also represented, and amusing them at luncheons and dinners, he knew very little of them really.

column2: To them he had always remained Mr. Arundel; no one called him Ferdinand; and he only knew the gossip also available to the evening papers and the frequenters of clubs.
column3: To them he had always remained mr Arundel; no one called him Ferdinand; and he only knew the gossip also available to the evening papers and the frequenters of clubs.

column2: But he was, however, good at inventing; and as soon as he had come to an end of first-hand knowledge, in order to answer her inquires and keep her there to himself he proceeded to invent.
column3: But he was, however, good at inventing; and as soon as he had come to an end of first-hand knowledge, in order to answer her inquires and keep her there to himself he proceeded to invent.

column2: It was quite easy to fasten some of the entertaining things he was constantly thinking on to other people and pretend they were theirs.
column3: It was quite easy to fasten some of the entertaining things he was constantly thinking on to other people and pretend they were theirs.

column2: Scrap, who had that affection for her parents which warms in absence, was athirst for news, and became more and more interested by the news he gradually imparted.
column3: Scrap, who had that affection for her parents which warms in absence, was athirst for news, and became more and more interested by the news he gradually imparted.

column2: At first it was ordinary news.
column3: At first it was ordinary news.

column2: He had met her mother here, and seen her there.
column3: He had met her mother here, and seen her there.

column2: She looked very well; she said so and so.
column3: She looked very well; she said so and so.

column2: But presently the things Lady Droitwich had said took on an unusual quality: they became amusing.
column3: But presently the things Lady Droitwich had said took on an unusual quality: they became amusing.

column2: Mother said that? Scrap interrupted, surprised.
column3: Mother said that? Scrap interrupted, surprised.

column2: And presently Lady Droitwich began to do amusing things as well as say them.
column3: And presently Lady Droitwich began to do amusing things as well as say them.

column2: Mother did that? Scrap inquired, wide-eyed.
column3: Mother did that? Scrap inquired, wide eyed.

column2: Arundel warmed to his work.
column3: Arundel warmed to his work.

column2: He fathered some of the most entertaining ideas he had lately had on to Lady Droitwich, and also any charming funny things that had been done--or might have been done, for he could imagine almost anything.
column3: He fathered some of the most entertaining ideas he had lately had on to Lady Droitwich, and also any charming funny things that had been done-or might have been done, for he could imagine almost anything.

column2: Scrap's eyes grew round with wonder and affectionate pride in her mother.
column3: Scrap's eyes grew round with wonder and affectionate pride in her mother.

column2: Why, but how funny---fancy mother.
column3: Why, but how funny---fancy mother.

column2: What an old darling.
column3: What an old darling.

column2: Did she really do that?
column3: Did she really do that?

column2: How perfectly adorable of her.
column3: How perfectly adorable of her.

column2: And did she really say--but how wonderful of her to think of it.
column3: And did she really say-but how wonderful of her to think of it.

column2: What sort of a face did Lloyd George make?
column3: What sort of a face did Lloyd George make?

column2: She laughed and laughed, and had a great longing to hug her mother, and the time flew, and it grew quite dusk, and it grew nearly dark, and Mr. Arundel still went on amusing her, and it was a quarter to eight before she suddenly remembered dinner.
column3: She laughed and laughed, and had a great longing to hug her mother, and the time flew, and it grew quite dusk, and it grew nearly dark, and mr Arundel still went on amusing her, and it was a quarter to eight before she suddenly remembered dinner.

column2: Oh, good heavens! she exclaimed, jumping up.
column3: Oh, good heavens! she exclaimed, jumping up.

column2: Yes.	Yes.

column2: It's late," said Arundel.
column3: It's late," said Arundel.

column2: I'll go on quickly and send the maid to you.	I'll go on quickly and send the maid to you.

column2: I must run, or I'll never be ready in time--"
column3: I must run, or I'll never be ready in time-"

column2: And she was gone up the path with the swiftness of a young, slender deer.
column3: And she was gone up the path with the swiftness of a young, slender deer.

column2: Arundel followed.
column3: Arundel followed.

column2: He did not wish to arrive too hot, so had to go slowly.
column3: He did not wish to arrive too hot, so had to go slowly.

column2: Fortunately he was near the top, and Francesca came down the pergola to pilot him indoors, and having shown him where he could wash she put him in the empty drawing-room to cool himself by the crackling wood fire.
column3: Fortunately he was near the top, and Francesca came down the pergola to pilot him indoors, and having shown him where he could wash she put him in the empty drawing room to cool himself by the crackling wood fire.

column2: He got as far away from the fire as he could, and stood in one of the deep window-recesses looking out at the distant lights of Mezzago. The drawing-room door was open, and the house was quiet with the hush that precedes dinner, when the inhabitants are all shut up in their rooms dressing.
column3: He got as far away from the fire as he could, and stood in one of the deep window recesses looking out at the distant lights of Mezzago. The drawing room door was open, and the house was quiet with the hush that precedes dinner, when the inhabitants are all shut up in their rooms dressing.

column2: Briggs in his room was throwing away spoilt tie after spoilt tie; Scrap in hers was hurrying into a black frock with a vague notion that Mr. Briggs wouldn't be able to see her so clearly in black; Mrs. Fisher was fastening the lace shawl, which nightly transformed her day dress into her evening dress, with the brooch Ruskin had given her on her marriage, formed of two pearl lilies tied together by a blue enamel ribbon on which was written in gold letters Esto perpetua; Mr. Wilkins was sitting on the edge of his bed brushing his wife's hair-- thus far in this third week had he progressed in demonstrativeness-- while she, for her part, sitting on a chair in front of him, put his studs in a clean shirt; and Rose, ready dressed, sat at her window considering her day.
column3: Briggs in his room was throwing away spoilt tie after spoilt tie; Scrap in hers was hurrying into a black frock with a vague notion that mr Briggs wouldn't be able to see her so clearly in black; mrs Fisher was fastening the lace shawl, which nightly transformed her day dress into her evening dress, with the brooch Ruskin had given her on her marriage, formed of two pearl lilies tied together by a blue enamel ribbon on which was written in gold letters Esto perpetua; mr Wilkins was sitting on the edge of his bed brushing his wife's hair- thus far in this third week had he progressed in demonstrativeness- while she, for her part, sitting on a chair in front of him, put his studs in a clean shirt; and Rose, ready dressed, sat at her window considering her day.

column2: Rose was quite aware of what had happened to Mr. Briggs.
column3: Rose was quite aware of what had happened to mr Briggs.

column2: If she had had any difficulty about it, Lotty would have removed it by the frank comments she made while she and Rose sat together after tea on the wall.
column3: If she had had any difficulty about it, Lotty would have removed it by the frank comments she made while she and Rose sat together after tea on the wall.

column2: Lotty was delighted at more love being introduced into San Salvatore, even if it were only one-sided, and said that when once Rose's husband was there she didn't suppose, now that Mrs. Fisher too had at last come unglued--Rose protested at the expression, and Lotty retorted that it was in Keats--there would be another place in the world more swarming with happiness than San Salvatore.
column3: Lotty was delighted at more love being introduced into San Salvatore, even if it were only one sided, and said that when once Rose's husband was there she didn't suppose, now that mrs Fisher too had at last come unglued-Rose protested at the expression, and Lotty retorted that it was in Keats-there would be another place in the world more swarming with happiness than San Salvatore.

column2: Your husband, said Lotty, swinging her feet, "might be here quite soon, perhaps to-morrow evening if he starts at once, and there'll be a glorious final few days before we all go home refreshed for life.
column3: Your husband, said Lotty, swinging her feet, "might be here quite soon, perhaps to morrow evening if he starts at once, and there'll be a glorious final few days before we all go home refreshed for life.

column2: I don't believe any of us will ever be the same again--and I wouldn't be a bit surprised if Caroline doesn't end by getting fond of the young man Briggs.
column3: I don't believe any of us will ever be the same again-and I wouldn't be a bit surprised if Caroline doesn't end by getting fond of the young man Briggs.

column2: It's in the air.
column3: It's in the air.

column2: You have to get fond of people here."
column3: You have to get fond of people here."

column2: Rose sat at her window thinking of these things.
column3: Rose sat at her window thinking of these things.

column2: Lotty's optimism . . . yet it had been justified by Mr. Wilkins; and look, too, at Mrs. Fisher.
column3: Lotty's optimism . . . yet it had been justified by mr Wilkins; and look, too, at mrs Fisher.

column2: If only it would come true as well about Frederick! For Rose, who between lunch and tea had left off thinking about Frederick, was now, between tea and dinner, thinking of him harder than ever.
column3: If only it would come true as well about Frederick! For Rose, who between lunch and tea had left off thinking about Frederick, was now, between tea and dinner, thinking of him harder than ever.

column2: It has been funny and delightful, that little interlude of admiration, but of course it couldn't go on once Caroline appeared. Rose knew her place.
column3: It has been funny and delightful, that little interlude of admiration, but of course it couldn't go on once Caroline appeared. Rose knew her place.

column2: She could see as well as any one the unusually, the unique loveliness of Lady Caroline.
column3: She could see as well as any one the unusually, the unique loveliness of Lady Caroline.

column2: How warm, though, things like admiration and appreciation made one feel, how capable of really deserving them, how different, how glowing.
column3: How warm, though, things like admiration and appreciation made one feel, how capable of really deserving them, how different, how glowing.

column2: They seemed to quicken unsuspected faculties into life.
column3: They seemed to quicken unsuspected faculties into life.

column2: She was sure she had been a thoroughly amusing woman between lunch and tea, and a pretty one too. She was quite certain she had been pretty; she saw it in Mr. Briggs's eyes as clearly as in a looking-glass.
column3: She was sure she had been a thoroughly amusing woman between lunch and tea, and a pretty one too. She was quite certain she had been pretty; she saw it in mr Briggs's eyes as clearly as in a looking glass.

column2: For a brief space, she thought, she had been like a torpid fly brought back to gay buzzing by the lighting of a fire in a wintry room.
column3: For a brief space, she thought, she had been like a torpid fly brought back to gay buzzing by the lighting of a fire in a wintry room.

column2: She still buzzed, she still tingled, just at the remembrance.
column3: She still buzzed, she still tingled, just at the remembrance.

column2: What fun it had been, having an admirer even for that little while.
column3: What fun it had been, having an admirer even for that little while.

column2: No wonder people liked admirers. They seemed, in some strange way, to make one come alive.
column3: No wonder people liked admirers. They seemed, in some strange way, to make one come alive.

column2: Although it was all over she still glowed with it and felt more exhilarated, more optimistic, more as Lotty probably constantly felt, than she had done since she was a girl.
column3: Although it was all over she still glowed with it and felt more exhilarated, more optimistic, more as Lotty probably constantly felt, than she had done since she was a girl.

column2: She dressed with care, though she knew Mr. Briggs would no longer see her, but it gave her pleasure to see how pretty, while she was about it, she could make herself look; and very nearly she stuck a crimson camellia in her hair down by her ear.
column3: She dressed with care, though she knew mr Briggs would no longer see her, but it gave her pleasure to see how pretty, while she was about it, she could make herself look; and very nearly she stuck a crimson camellia in her hair down by her ear.

column2: She did hold it there for a minute, and it looked almost sinfully attractive and was exactly the colour of her mouth, but she took it out again with a smile and a sigh and put it in the proper place for flowers, which is water.
column3: She did hold it there for a minute, and it looked almost sinfully attractive and was exactly the colour of her mouth, but she took it out again with a smile and a sigh and put it in the proper place for flowers, which is water.

column2: She mustn't be silly, she thought.
column3: She mustn't be silly, she thought.

column2: Think of the poor.
column3: Think of the poor.

column2: Soon she would be back with them again, and what would a camellia behind her ear seem like then?
column3: Soon she would be back with them again, and what would a camellia behind her ear seem like then?

column2: Simply fantastic.
column3: Simply fantastic.

column2: But on one thing she was determined: the first thing she would do when she got home would be to have it out with Frederick.
column3: But on one thing she was determined: the first thing she would do when she got home would be to have it out with Frederick.

column2: If he didn't come to San Salvatore that is what she would do--the very first thing. Long ago she ought to have done this, but always she had been handicapped, when she tried to, by being so dreadfully fond of him and so much afraid that fresh wounds were going to be given her wretched, soft heart.
column3: If he didn't come to San Salvatore that is what she would do-the very first thing. Long ago she ought to have done this, but always she had been handicapped, when she tried to, by being so dreadfully fond of him and so much afraid that fresh wounds were going to be given her wretched, soft heart.

column2: But now let him wound her as much as he chose, as much as he possibly could, she would still have it out with him.
column3: But now let him wound her as much as he chose, as much as he possibly could, she would still have it out with him.

column2: Not that he ever intentionally wounded her; she knew he never meant to, she knew he often had no idea of having done it.
column3: Not that he ever intentionally wounded her; she knew he never meant to, she knew he often had no idea of having done it.

column2: For a person who wrote books, thought Rose, Frederick didn't seem to have much imagination.
column3: For a person who wrote books, thought Rose, Frederick didn't seem to have much imagination.

column2: Anyhow, she said to herself, getting up from the dressing-table, things couldn't go on like this.
column3: Anyhow, she said to herself, getting up from the dressing table, things couldn't go on like this.

column2: She would have it out with him.
column3: She would have it out with him.

column2: This separate life, this freezing loneliness, she had had enough of it.
column3: This separate life, this freezing loneliness, she had had enough of it.

column2: Why shouldn't she too be happy?
column3: Why shouldn't she too be happy?

column2: Why on earth--the energetic expression matched her mood of rebelliousness--shouldn't she too be loved and allowed to love?
column3: Why on earth-the energetic expression matched her mood of rebelliousness-shouldn't she too be loved and allowed to love?

column2: She looked at her little clock.
column3: She looked at her little clock.

column2: Still ten minutes before dinner. Tired of staying in her bedroom she thought she would go on to Mrs. Fisher's battlements, which would be empty at this hour, and watch the moon rise out of the sea.
column3: Still ten minutes before dinner. Tired of staying in her bedroom she thought she would go on to mrs Fisher's battlements, which would be empty at this hour, and watch the moon rise out of the sea.

column2: She went into the deserted upper hall with this intention, but was attracted on her way along it by the firelight shining through the open door of the drawing-room.
column3: She went into the deserted upper hall with this intention, but was attracted on her way along it by the firelight shining through the open door of the drawing room.

column2: How gay it looked.
column3: How gay it looked.

column2: The fire transformed the room.
column3: The fire transformed the room.

column2: A dark, ugly room in the daytime, it was transformed just as she had been transformed by the warmth of--no, she wouldn't be silly; she would think of the poor; the thought of them always brought her down to sobriety at once.
column3: A dark, ugly room in the daytime, it was transformed just as she had been transformed by the warmth of-no, she wouldn't be silly; she would think of the poor; the thought of them always brought her down to sobriety at once.

column2: She peeped in.
column3: She peeped in.

column2: Firelight and flowers; and outside the deep slits of windows hung the blue curtain of the night.
column3: Firelight and flowers; and outside the deep slits of windows hung the blue curtain of the night.

column2: How pretty.
column3: How pretty.

column2: What a sweet place San Salvatore was.
column3: What a sweet place San Salvatore was.

column2: And that gorgeous lilac on the table-- she must go and put her face in it . . .
column3: And that gorgeous lilac on the table- she must go and put her face in it . . .

column2: But she never got to the lilac.
column3: But she never got to the lilac.

column2: She went one step towards it, and then stood still, for she had seen the figure looking out of the window in the farthest corner, and it was Frederick.
column3: She went one step towards it, and then stood still, for she had seen the figure looking out of the window in the farthest corner, and it was Frederick.

column2: All the blood in Rose's body rushed to her heart and seemed to stop its beating.
column3: All the blood in Rose's body rushed to her heart and seemed to stop its beating.

column2: She stood quite still.
column3: She stood quite still.

column2: He had not heard her.
column3: He had not heard her.

column2: He did not turn round.
column3: He did not turn round.

column2: She stood looking at him.
column3: She stood looking at him.

column2: The miracle had happened, and he had come.
column3: The miracle had happened, and he had come.

column2: She stood holding her breath.
column3: She stood holding her breath.

column2: So he needed her, for he had come instantly.
column3: So he needed her, for he had come instantly.

column2: So he too must have been thinking, longing . . .
column3: So he too must have been thinking, longing . . .

column2: Her heart, which had seemed to stop beating, was suffocating her now, the way it raced along.
column3: Her heart, which had seemed to stop beating, was suffocating her now, the way it raced along.

column2: Frederick did love her then--he must love her, or why had he come?
column3: Frederick did love her then-he must love her, or why had he come?

column2: Something, perhaps her absence, had made him turn to her, want her . . . and now the understanding she had made up her mind to have with him would be quite--would be quite--easy--
column3: Something, perhaps her absence, had made him turn to her, want her . . . and now the understanding she had made up her mind to have with him would be quite-would be quite-easy-

column2: Her thoughts wouldn't go on.
column3: Her thoughts wouldn't go on.

column2: Her mind stammered.
column3: Her mind stammered.

column2: She couldn't think.
column3: She couldn't think.

column2: She could only see and feel.
column3: She could only see and feel.

column2: She didn't know how it had happened.
column3: She didn't know how it had happened.

column2: It was a miracle.
column3: It was a miracle.

column2: God could do miracles.
column3: God could do miracles.

column2: God had done this one.
column3: God had done this one.

column2: God could--God could--could--
column3: God could-God could-could-

column2: Her mind stammered again, and broke off.
column3: Her mind stammered again, and broke off.

column2: Frederick-- she tried to say; but no sound came, or if it did the crackling of the fire covered it up.
column3: Frederick- she tried to say; but no sound came, or if it did the crackling of the fire covered it up.

column2: She must go nearer.
column3: She must go nearer.

column2: She began to creep towards him--softly, softly.
column3: She began to creep towards him-softly, softly.

column2: He did not move.
column3: He did not move.

column2: He had not heard.
column3: He had not heard.

column2: She stole nearer and nearer, and the fire crackled and he heard nothing.
column3: She stole nearer and nearer, and the fire crackled and he heard nothing.

column2: She stopped a moment, unable to breathe.
column3: She stopped a moment, unable to breathe.

column2: She was afraid. Suppose he--suppose he--oh, but he had come, he had come.
column3: She was afraid. Suppose he-suppose he-oh, but he had come, he had come.

column2: She went on again, close up to him, and her heart beat so loud that she thought he must hear it.
column3: She went on again, close up to him, and her heart beat so loud that she thought he must hear it.

column2: And couldn't he feel--didn't he know--
column3: And couldn't he feel-didn't he know-

column2: Frederick, she whispered, hardly able even to whisper, choked by the beating of her heart.
column3: Frederick, she whispered, hardly able even to whisper, choked by the beating of her heart.

column2: He spun round on his heels.
column3: He spun round on his heels.

column2: Rose! he exclaimed, staring blankly.
column3: Rose! he exclaimed, staring blankly.

column2: But she did not see his stare, for her arms were round his neck, and her cheek was against his, and she was murmuring, her lips on his ear, "I knew you would come--in my very heart I always, always knew you would come--"
column3: But she did not see his stare, for her arms were round his neck, and her cheek was against his, and she was murmuring, her lips on his ear, "I knew you would come-in my very heart I always, always knew you would come-"
